documentation.title: API Documentation
documentation.intro: Here you can find out all about how to make GraphQL calls. Remember you will need your developer key which you can always find on the main Developers Help page, but it's also here:
documentation.note: NOTE: This documentation is very new and evolving but should be enough to get you up and running, we will be expanding it in the near future.
documentation.must-be-logged-in: You must be logged in to see the documentation
documentation.nesting: Nesting objects in constituents and constituents in objects
documentation.objects-connected-constituent: Finding objects connected to a constituent
documentation.graphql-about-1: GraphQL is a data query language you'll use to request information from the M+ data store. Traditionally GraphQL allows two types of operations, queries and mutations these can be thought of as read and write operations.
documentation.graphql-about-2: As well as one more operation called introspection, which allows you to ask the GraphQL endpoint about itself.
documentation.graphql-about-3: Below you will find examples of various calls to can make to the GraphQL endpoint.
documentation.graphql-communicating-1: The single endpoint for all GraphQL calls is...
documentation.graphql-communicating-2: GraphQL operations consist of multiline JSON, an example "Hello World" GraphQL query is show below:
documentation.graphql-communicating-3: To query GraphQL using cURL, make a POST request with a JSON payload as --data-binary. You must also include your API token as bearer authorization.
documentation.graphql-communicating-4: Using Nodejs it may look like this, making sure to pass in your API token as a bearer token as shown.
documentation.graphql-communicating-5: Probably the easiest way to try out GraphQL queries is to use the playground which can be found here:
documentation.graphql-communicating-6: You can see an example by clicking the "run in the playground" link, you will need to press the "run" button to see the results of the query.
documentation.graphql-communicating-7: Below you'll find a list of the current queries you can make against the data store.
documentation.graphql-introspection-1: The introspection operation is the only operation you can call using GET. Introspection allows you to query the GraphQL schema for details about itself. Query __schema to list all types defined in the schema and get details about each:
documentation.graphql-introspection-2: Query __type to get details about any type:
documentation.graphql-objects-1: This query selects all of the objects and can be filtered by certain fields shown below. Note: filters are additive rather than or, filtering two fields will only return records that match both.
documentation.graphql-objects-2: Valid filters are: page, per_page, [ids], lang, sort, sort_field, objectNumber, area, category, archivalLevel, medium, title, displayDate, beginDate, endDate, constituent, [constituents], exhibition, and keyword
documentation.graphql-objects-3: Valid values for the sort_field are id, objectNumber, sortNumber, title, displayDate, beginDate, endDate, popularCount, area, medium, archivalLevel and category, values for sort are asc and desc.
documentation.valid-lang: The only valid values for lang are en, and zh-hant. The default is en, if a record doesn't have values that match the selected language then it'll return the en version if there is one.
documentation.graphql-objects-5: Here is the simplest call to get all object ids
documentation.object-pagination: Here we are asking for slightly more information, note how we can use the per_page filter to limit the number of results.
documentation.object-sort-example: Here is an example of sorting by sortNumber.
documentation.object-by-ids-example: You can also ask for specific objects by passing in an array of ids.
documentation.object-1: You can get a single object by passing in the id parameter. Here we are showing all the fields possible.
documentation.areas-1: You can fetch all the valid areas which you can then use to filter objects by. For example running the query below will return a handful of areas, which you would then use in an Object query with (area: "xxxxxxxx") where "xxxxxxxx" is one of the areas returned by this query.
documentation.aggs-filters: Valid filters are page, per_page, lang, sort and sort_field.
documentation.aggs-sort: Valid values for the sort_field are title and count. Valid values for the sort are asc and desc.
documentation.aggs-per-page: The per_page filter will limit the number of results, for example (per_page: 10) will return just 10 records. Unlike Objects you cannot paginate through the this data set.
documentation.category-1: You can fetch all the valid categories which you can then use to filter objects by. For example running the query below will return a handful of categories, which you would then use in an Object query with (category: "xxxxxxxx") where "xxxxxxxx" is one of the categories returned by this query.
documentation.medium-1: You can fetch all the valid mediums which you can then use to filter objects by. For example running the query below will return a handful of mediums, which you would then use in an Object query with (medium: "xxxxxxxx") where "xxxxxxxx" is one of the mediums returned by this query.
documentation.archivalLevel-1: You can fetch all the valid archival levels which you can then use to filter objects by. For example running the query below will return a handful of levels, which you would then use in an Object query with (archivalLevel: "xxxxxxxx") where "xxxxxxxx" is one of the level returned by this query.
documentation.constituents-1: Constituents are people and institutions connected to an object, for example they may be the artists or the seller or buyer, they may be the curator or the institution the displays the object.
documentation.constituents-2: This query selects all of the constituents and can be filtered by certain fields shown below. Note: filters are additive rather than or, filtering two fields will only return records that match both.
documentation.constituents-filters: Valid filters are: page, per_page, sort_field, sort, [ids], gender, name, gender, beginDate, endDate, keyword, isMaker, role and lang
documentation.constituents-sorts: Valid values for the sort_field are id, name, sortNumber, alphaSortName, gender, beginDate, endDate, objectCount and nationality, values for sort are asc and desc.

documentation.constituents-more-info: Here we are asking for slightly more information, note how we can use the per_page filter to limit the number of results.
documentation.constituents-sorting: Here is an example of sorting by alphaSortName.
documentation.constituents-by-ids-example: You can also ask for specific constituents by passing in an array of ids.
documentation.constituent-1: You can get a single constituent by passing in the id parameter. Here we are showing all the fields possible.
documentation.nesting-1: When you are searching for objects you can nest a limited version of constituents in the results. If you are requesting Objects you can get the constituents with the following query.
documentation.nesting-2: If you are asking for a single Object then you can get a bit more information about the constituents, see the example below.
documentation.nesting-3: You cannot keep nesting objects and constituents beyond the first two levels, because they would just keep including each other forever.
documentation.nesting-4: You can also next constituents inside objects, but again with limited information returned and only down two levels.

aboutapi.body:
About the M+ API

Background#

M+ is embracing open access and working towards releasing as much of our collections metadata as possible. Our goal is to unlock the museum’s institutional knowledge and release it into the public domain, driven by M+’s mission as a public institution. Read more about our open access journey here and here.

We’ve released an open data set here, but are also sharing our data through a public API to help increase access and encourage creative projects. The M+ API will be available for anyone who’d like to work with it. It’s for developers, designers, artists, creators—anyone who’s curious about telling stories through data.

The Data#

The data made available to you through this API service is a reflection of institutional knowledge developed over time at M+. This data has been created by curators, registrars, researchers, and scholars working in collaboration with M+ to describe, express, and interpret the objects held in the M+ Collections. This data is made available to you, the public, as CC0 Open Data and through this API service, for use by your websites, applications, and research projects.

This data is provided ‘as is’ for research purposes and you may use it at your own risk. Documentation of the museum’s collection is an ongoing process and we are continuing to research and enrich our collections data. We will update the dataset with new and revised information on a regular basis. M+ makes no representations or warranties of any kind on this data.

Technical documentation and access#

To access this API you must register for an account here. All calls to the API require an API key, which will be granted to you upon registration of your account.

For information on making use of this API, please see the technical documentation made available here.

termsofuse.body:
Terms of use

General

  • If you make use of this service, you are deemed to have accepted the terms and conditions listed here.
  • This data is provided ‘as is’ for research purposes and you may use it at your own risk.
  • Do not mislead others or misrepresent the data made available through this API.
  • You must not use the M+ trademark or derivatives of the M+ name, or otherwise claim or imply that M+ endorses you or your use of the data made available through this API.
  • Whenever you transform, translate, or otherwise modify this data, you must make it clear that the resulting information has been modified. If you enrich or otherwise modify the data, please consider publishing the derived data without reuse restrictions.
  • You may not use the M+ logo or brand on your website without the specific written permission of M+.
  • M+ reserves the right to extend or alter these terms and conditions at any time.

Rules of the road

  • M+ kindly requests that you inform us about your use of the API by emailing us a link to your project and describing how you are using this API service.
  • Additionally, M+ kindly requests that you actively acknowledge and give attribution to M+ wherever possible. If you use this dataset, please cite M+ as the source, using
    • the digital object identifier [####], and
    • the formal acknowledgement/attribution ‘source: M+, Hong Kong’, and
    • a link to our website: mplus.org.hk.
  • M+ is periodically updating the data provided by this API. We ask that you not cache or store any content returned by the M+ API for more than two weeks without refreshing the data. If your application requires long term data caching, we ask that you contact us.
  • We reserve the right to turn off or modify the API service at any time.
  • We reserve the right to block or cancel your access to the API service without prior notice.
  • While the data made available through this API is licensed as CC0 data, the API service itself is meant for non-commercial use only. If you plan to use this service for commercial purposes, please contact us.
  • Respect other users of the API by limiting the number of API calls to 3,000 per day, or 2 calls per second.We reserve the right to limit or suspend your use of the API if you exceed these rate limits.

The writers of these guidelines thank Harvard Art Museumsand Cooper-Hewitt.

Contact us

Please contact us here with any questions regarding the API.
